Award.AwardTitle: Lincoln's Excellent Academic Program in Science: Forward March

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Lincoln University's implementation project - Lincoln's Excellent Academic Program in Science: Forward March - consolidates and sustains the efforts of previous awards to significantly increase the pool of minority students pursuing degrees and careers in the sciences. The goals of this project are: 1) to improve students' learning and study skills and their commitment to succeed in college, and thereby increase the retention and graduation rates of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) majors; 2) to enhance students' preparation and readiness for professional and graduate school; 3) to increase the STEM research capacity at Lincoln University; and 4) to increase the recruitment of STEM majors at Lincoln University.

These goals will be realized through consolidating the Supplemental Instruction program for high risk STEM courses, institutionalizing a STEM undergraduate research program, increasing the number of faculty with research grants, increasing the number of STEM graduates accepted to graduate and professional schools, and increasing the number of students enrolled and retained in STEM programs.

The project emphasizes two key activities - improved retention in STEM gate-keeping and bottleneck courses and integration of student research and other active-learning opportunities into the STEM curriculum. The project strives to provide a model of educating minority students in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. We significantly increased the number of faculty involved in grants activities since the award of LEAPS-FM. There are nine new faculty with grants (Baskerville; Semychayevskky; Hull; Royer; Miller; Sun; Gallagher; Gray; Safford). Preliminary data for the grants came from support from the faculty/student collaboration provided through the LEAPS-FM grant.
  2. We exceeded the number of trained SI leaders each year of the grant. During the tenure of the grant, we trained a total of 190 SI leaders. The average of 19.0 SI leaders per semester far exceeds the target of 18 per semester in the proposal.
  3. We trained and utilized a total of 16.5 faculty each semester of the grant to support SI activities. These faculty will be able to use their SI training to improve retention even after the end of the grant.
  4. During the duration of the grant, we covered every gate keeping course. A total of 244 courses were supported in ten semesters for an average of 24.4 courses per semester.
  5. SI has significantly increased retention in gate keeping courses, resulting in a demand for its implementation in non-gate-keeping and non-STEM courses. An average of 497 students benefited from the SI program each semester. As a result of this support to the retention effort, the university is planning to introduce SI in other programs outside STEM.
  6. The number of faculty and students research teams have increased significantly since the award of LEAPS-FM. From 2005 to 2011, only 5 of 194 posters (2.6%) presented at Lincoln’s Annual Science Fair came from faculty student collaboration. From 2012 to 2015, the number of presentations from faculty/student collaborations has significantly increased to 28.3% (39 of 138 posters).
  7. The cumulative total number of student researchers supported over a five year period was 101 instead of the proposed target of 45 students, a significant increase of 124%. On the faculty side there was a cumulative total number of 29 faculty research mentees who participated in the project over a period of five years instead of the projected 15, amounting to an increase of 93%.
  8. We were able to enable 39 students to take the GRE and other post-graduation examinations of which 26 (67%) were accepted to graduate or professional schools.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: John O Chikwem
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We significantly increased the number of faculty involved in grants activities since the award of LEAPS-FM. There are nine new faculty with grants (Baskerville; Semychayevskky; Hull; Royer; Miller; Sun; Gallagher; Gray; Safford). Preliminary data for the grants came from support from the faculty/student collaboration provided through the LEAPS-FM grant. We exceeded the number of trained SI leaders each year of the grant. During the tenure of the grant, we trained a total of 190 SI leaders. The average of 19.0 SI leaders per semester far exceeds the target of 18 per semester in the proposal. We trained and utilized a total of 16.5 faculty each semester of the grant to support SI activities. These faculty will be able to use their SI training to improve retention even after the end of the grant. During the duration of the grant, we covered every gate keeping course. A total of 244 courses were supported in ten semesters for an average of 24.4 courses per semester. SI has significantly increased retention in gate keeping courses, resulting in a demand for its implementation in non-gate-keeping and non-STEM courses. An average of 497 students benefited from the SI program each semester. As a result of this support to the retention effort, the university is planning to introduce SI in other programs outside STEM. The number of faculty and students research teams have increased significantly since the award of LEAPS-FM. From 2005 to 2011, only 5 of 194 posters (2.6%) presented at Lincoln?s Annual Science Fair came from faculty student collaboration. From 2012 to 2015, the number of presentations from faculty/student collaborations has significantly increased to 28.3% (39 of 138 posters). The cumulative total number of student researchers supported over a five year period was 101 instead of the proposed target of 45 students, a significant increase of 124%. On the faculty side there was a cumulative total number of 29 faculty research mentees who participated in the project over a period of five years instead of the projected 15, amounting to an increase of 93%. We were able to enable 39 students to take the GRE and other post-graduation examinations of which 26 (67%) were accepted to graduate or professional schools.
